number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 15, 2015
												This is an okay game, which is sad, because it feels like it could have been a great game.In brief, you play James Quatermain, the grandson of H. Rider Haggard's Allan Quatermain, a fictional big game hunter who spent most of his life in Africa, seeking to improve the lives of the native people without destroying their culture--so, Allan wasn't a terrible guy, and the simple fact is...the game should have been about him. In their desire to emulate all the Quatermain knockoffs, primarily Indiana Jones, the developers instead make an Indiana Jones knockoff. You fight Nazis who are trying to steal some ancient relics that are mysterious sources of power, bring a potential love interest along, have, for a while, a wise cracking cohort (somewhat surprisingly a German), and solve puzzles while ruining ancient tombs. So, the story is somewhat lacking.Gameplay wise, it's nothing special. Combat works alright. There's a limit cover mechanic, though shooting out of it isn't smooth, grenades aren't devastating to you or your enemies. There's a flashlight mechanic for dealing with risen mummies that's straight out of a horror game, and even on higher difficulty settings makes them the least dangerous enemies except in occasional swarms.There's a system for increasing your skills and attributes, but you could go the entire game without doing it and not suffer. It works based on locating artifacts that give you points, and a sufficient number of points let you up things like health, stamina, weapon reload time, the flashlight enhancing skill, and so on. But, again, their help is minimal, and it feels tacked on. Also tacked on: treasure maps that show you where the artifacts are, but without a birds eye view for location context, they're not all that useful.The puzzles are kind of fun, but if you take too long, your female companion starts spouting off a helpful line of dialogue--just one, over and over and over, until you want to shoot her.Things that would've added greatly: Better characterization. The sexual tension was laughable, and the script could definitely use a once-over. More back and forth between the characters would've actually been okay for those long walks between combat sessions, while the combat dialogue could've used more than the female character always complaining that the Nazis were moving closer to her. This was especially true in one hilarious context in which she was nowhere near the action, just waiting for me to take a standard slow video game elevator down while under fire. She was in literally no danger, and just kept repeating that one line over and over.A better spread of weapons, or modifiable weapons, would've been nice.Some sort of stealth mechanic would've actually gone a long way. You disarm occasional traps, how about setting some?And, finally, the lead character feels wrong. If the devs wanted to do a story in Quatermain's universe, how about doing one about Quatermain?I feel like this is one of those rare instances where a sequel could outshine its original. It's a pretty firm 7/10. Grab it on sale, play it once, forget about it.

												I usually reserve reviews until I finish the game, but I am confident I will do so.  I think it's a ton of fun.  I'm playing on hard puzzles (though that's a bit of an exaggeration) and medium combat (although I could probably bump it up to hard since I haven't had any trouble there either).  I think it's a good mix of exploration and action.  The dialogue could use some work but that's about my only complaint, and I quite like that the combat is limited to areas where you know there are going to be bad guys and it isn't like the similarly themed game, the Ball, where you have to handle the combat and exploring/puzzling at the same time.About my only complaint is that it's easy to leave an area accidentally and then you can never return; so it's possible I've missed a few secrets but I will never know.  I wouldn't mind a confirmation screen and one which tells me to what percent I've completed the area.

content:
Posted: February 28, 2014
												Combine the most annoying problems in PC gaming (texture popping, fiddly controls) with boring adventure movie cliches and you get Deadfall Adventures! Witness the most boring game to ever feature an action sequence within 5 minutes of the gameplay starting which also takes another 15 minutes of cutscenes which are completely pointless to get to! Broken shooting mechanics which make the game unintentionally difficult at times! A starter weapon which is completely useless to begin with and hitboxes so small, they would make Carlton look like Andre The Giant.Voice acting so bad it makes Facade look like Metal Gear Solid in comparison, graphics that don't really look that great to begin with and generic characters so generic that you lose the complete ability to be interested in them or involved in their boring stories.Please do not buy this game. The screenshots might look pretty and the premise might seem good at first, but the game itself is a broken, boring and useless mess. Play something else; anything else!

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 15, 2015
												Well I missed this game when it first came out and thanks to an online buddy for turning me on to it! I'm having quite a bit of fun with it. Nordic Games have a bright future, they are still rough around the edges a bit and certain areas of this game could've been more polished (voice-acting being my biggest complaint). The core gameplay keeps me playing through and it has enough variety to keep me entertained throughout thanks to scenery changes and the different types of enemies. Yes, the combat could be a bit better but I really like how the guns feel and sound quite authentic. If you see this game available at a reasonable price and you are a fan of action-adventure games (i.e. the new Tomb Raider reboot...which I thought was amazing and the Uncharted games) this game is right up your alley. Being a fan of Indiana Jones does help a bit too! :) Forget the awful Alan Quartermaine movies from the 80's though... although this game's voice acting isn't top notch it's still better than those movies! The developer listens to the community (just look what they did with Red Faction G! They totally ripped out GFWL and have put a lot of time and effort implimenting community suggestions and the game is now better than ever. The reboot of Painkiller they did was also well done although I wish they'd do a completely NEW title for the franchise and make it great to get recognition. Well to sum it all up this game is a fun romp (even the multiplayer is decent) and I'd most certainly recommend it to any FPS fan who doesn't expect AAA titles with every game they play. Play this game knowing it could be better but enjoy it for what it is! Nordic Games have a bright future indeed and I'll be keeping my eye on them for sure.

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 25, 2015
"Arctic Nazi Submarine Mummies? Any other time that might be unusual."Deadfall Adventures is a decent first person shooter, action adventure game, with fun puzzles and beautiful graphics, but with voice acting, dialogue, and repetitive combat that brings it down. Good idea that seemed rushed, unpolished, and left with untapped potential. Worth one playthrough of decent length, not much to come back for though.*Gameplay*+ Decently fun, good distraction+ Some great puzzles- A lot of tedious and/or boring puzzles+ Combat is mildly entertaining+ Mummies!- Repetitive combatSome very cool, and interesting puzzles, surrounded by many tedious, boring puzzles that bring down the overall quiality of the game. Combat is fun but gets repetitive quite quickly, but having mummies and occasionally changing the weapons and appearance of enemies helps keep it sort of interesting.*Graphics*+ Beautiful Environments+ Amazing Graphics, the water, plants, ect, all looked great- Not enough varietyAmazingly looking graphics and beautiful environments throughout the game. Plants, water, enemies, temples, everything looks well-polished, but what it makes up for in quality, it lacks in variety. Many environments ( which takes place in different parts of the world ) look almost identical with little variation.*Dialogue/Cutscenes/Story*+ Occasionally something interesting would happen+ Decent story- Slow quite often- Painful, PAINFUL dialogue- Clunky cutscenesThe story in Deadfall Adventures is mildly interesting at best, with only a few moments of actual true interest, despite it being quite predictable. Slow throughout the whole game, clunky cutscenes that are badly executed, and some of the worst dialogue I have seen in a game in a while. It was cringe worthy half the time and the other half I simply felt embarrassed for them.*Exploration/Adventuring Aspect*+ Fun side puzzles occasionally+ Feel like you're actually on an adventure at times- Pretty linear path- Minimal actual "exploration" (More just looking around in a decently sized area for a shiny)The exploration aspect is almost non-existent, however; they have mini puzzles when attempting to retrieve artifacts that make them interesting enough for me to look for them. You are basically on one path, look around the area for artifacts you can find, move on to the next area, and get locked out from going back, forcing you to replay an entire section if you wish to go back. *Overall*I recommend this game, but get it on sale. It is entertaining enough to play through, collect what artifacts you can, and enjoy a decently engaging story (if you can get passed the very painful, and often times embarrassing dialogue).Good for one playthrough, wouldn't go back for a second time, but good enough game to pass the time. Very good idea, but feels rushed and badly executed throughout. Decent combat and fun puzzles bring this game up, but frustrating, tedious puzzles, and repetitive combat situations bring the game down in quality and enjoyment. I personally did not try multiplayer as I have zero interest, considering I disliked the combat in singleplayer.Buy it on sale.

												An action adventure in spirit, a joyful ride FPS in actuality.   The game is a mix between the movies of Indiana Jones and Allan Quatermain, with a touch of Tomb Raider and a taste of Alan Wake, in first person.You are on an adventure which will take you through several locations, trying to end this well.  There are plenty of underground locations and some above.  There are lovely cutscenes and beautiful scenery to enjoy.  According to Steam stats it took me about 12 hours to complete on average difficulty.  Sounds about right.  Don't take it too seriously and you will enjoy it for what it is.  A fun ride.  I was 100% satisfied for what I got for my money.  I do hope there is going to be a sequel at least in spirit. content:
Posted: December 2, 2014
												Deadfall Adventures is an exploration-oriented, first-person adventure game with some shooting and puzzles, including puzzles that involve shooting and shooting sequences that require solving puzzles to survive them.The story is a typical Quatermain-style adventure - while it won't win a Hugo, if you like punching Nazis, shooting Commies, immolating mummies, or applying dynamite to irreplaceable archeological treasures, there is something here for you. The fighting sequences are mainly creative and well done - I enjoyed them more than, say, Bioshock Infinite's. The puzzles are generally straightforward, but they establish a nice, relaxed pace between the high-tension action segments. I took about 20 hours to play through the single-player campaign - I attempted to collect most of the optional treasures, at least the ones that were semi-obvious, along the way. "Normal" difficulty combat was perfectly doable with a gamepad - if you're using a mouse, I'd bump it up to "Hard."Thanks to The Farm 51 and Nordic Games for porting this to Linux - I played the complete game on Ubuntu 14.04 x86-64. There are a couple of technical issues, but I'm not sure if they're Linux-specific or not: Load times are massive, over 5 minutes for a "cold start"; the gamepad mappings are odd - "Jump" and "Use" are mapped to the same button, so you need to hold LB to interact with things (or perform mêlée attacks), which simultaneously toggles your flashlight.Overall, I would recommend this game to fans of the genre.

												not sure about how the story is, or the competitive multiplayer, but the survival mode is definitely... lacking. I spent only a short time playing it during the free weekend, and all I can say is, with 2 players and on EASY, the enemies are near invulnerable (takes all your ammo to kill ONE of the weaker enemies), and the easiest method to kill them is to make use of the dozens of traps placed around each of the maps. This makes for very dull gameplay, where you feel like scooby doo on the run from a bad guy, just running around, and timing the traps which you have to SHOOT to activate, and kill the enemies with.Could have been better, but if the easiest survival mode was this dull, I can only imagine how awful the competitive is, and how dull the campaign must be. If the campaign were COOP it would give the game some redemption, but its not, sadly. The story looks like it could be interesting but I have no interest in playing through this game alone.

number of helpful: 6 of 10 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 8, 2015
												This game desperately wants to be the Indiana Jones action-adventure game that never existed.  To some extent, it succeeds, riding on the coattails of a lot of what made Raiders of the Lost Ark and Allan Quatermain great.  Unfortunately, dull combat against hordes of nearly identical enemies that don't do much doesn't help matters, and although many of the puzzles are pretty good (and the "notepad" hint system nice), and the environs mostly pretty, there's a sad repetitiveness to it and the acting is bluntly pretty bad.  The section in the ice temple area seems to drag on way too long.  Basically, the game seems like it was rushed or incomplete... more time needed to be invested in enemy design and AI and more variety in the shootybangs sequences.  All in all, just kind of "meh".

content:
Posted: December 12, 2015
												This is a must have game, especially if you're a Linux user! I'd say the game is somewhere between Wolfenstein and Tomb Raider. Very well constructed and designed. Sensible and absolutely enjoyable, apart from a few annoying parts, that you have to do over and over again. But, which game doesn't have those parts? It's a FPS, but some puzzle to tackle with, which makes it more interesting. So it's not just shoot them up and that's it. Very colour full and the environment is keep changing throughout the game. I'd say it's getting more and more difficult to find a good game out there lately. It's all about zombies these days, which I find very boring. Although, this has some of them too, I still feel like it's a spot on game. Think about Return to castle of Wolfenstein. Probably it's the closest game I'd mention. Very sorry for the lack of Linux support. The game freezes very often when a video or some additional data is about to be loaded. Starting of the game is a little bit long, but be patient it's worth it. Sometimes, it's just stops and you have to restart the game. If you are a Linux user, as I've mentioned it, it's a must have game, not only for the fun but for the support as well. You won't be disappointed.Hoping this game will become a series.

content:
Posted: November 3, 2014
												I am trying not to let my loathing of the protagonist and his companion color my review too much, but if you have an option to turn off the spoken dialog and go with subtitles you will probably enjoy the game much more. I am playing the game on Normal/Normal. Probably should up the combat difficulty as the soldiers and Dark enemies really are kind of a joke. Puzzle difficulty is hard enough for me as these are more distractions than the whole point of the game for me. The notebook pretty much gives you the answer to any puzzle you HAVE to get past, Weapon variety is good, and you are given the tools to get through each level - so much so that you pretty much know what is going to happen next just by seeing what is laying around. The mine cart scenes where too much. WAY too much of a steal from Indiana jones for a game that is already riding firmly on Indie's coat tails. Plus, these scenes are of little interest. I think you could really just sit there and not bother shooting or looking around and you would end up with the same results. The game claims to be about exploration - but does not give you the opportunity in many places. You are not sure which areas trigger a level transition and which do not, so if you happen down the wrong path at some point you can no longer retrieve the treasures that trigger your character progression. The game is worth what I paid for it (~$9) but you would feel gipped if you paid more.

content:
Posted: January 22
												This game is one of the few games that pay homage to a book/comic set that do it well. I went into this game with low expectations to be honest, it didn't look like it would get my attention. After finishing it i went straight to look at the books and fell in love with the lore of it all.The score of this game is fantastic for its setting and style. The voice acting, could be a little better but is at least decent. The characters are fully fleshed out, including the sarcastic s*** you play as that you can't help but like. The guns are standard, but that is not what this game is about, the puzzles are where this game shines. The game essentially gives you the answer to every puzzle in a book you can hold in game, but doing a play through without its help makes the game even better.My only thing that really annoyed me is the final boss, it does not tell you what to do and it is a bit of a weird one, as *spoiler alert* you have to look up and blow up something*. All in all, great game even with all the nay sayers in the review section.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 28, 2015
												If you're one of those who likes the Indiana Jones movies and the Uncharted games, then this might be a game for you. It's a first person shooter where you shoot yourself through a temple in Egypt, a temple in the Arctic, the "Mayan" jungle and also a Mayan temple... as earlier stated; Much like Indiana Jones and Uncharted.The year is 1938, you take the role as James Lee Quatermain and he gets the mission to escort Jennifer Goodwin into a temple in Egypt - go in, get the thing she's after and then get out, that kind of job. But as you're probably aware of, things go south... quickly. And you need to set things right. That's a simple way to explain the story.It looks GREAT. They did a great job (for the most part) with the models (the lip syncing went haywire towards the end of the game) and textures and environments, but when it comes to sound... that leaves a whole lot to be desired. The voice acting is not very good at all. Although the music is decent. The AI is hit and miss, sometimes it rushes you for no good reason, sometimes it just stays behind cover for no reason.So, in short, the game is "hit and miss". It's fun, keeps the player entertained throughout the eight hour long "Adventure" mode and there's a lot of puzzles throughout, most required to complete to be able to continue. But there shouldn't be any issues completing them, not if you're asking me. I bought the game for €3.99 and I wouldn't go over that if interested in buying it.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 21, 2016
												So Deadfall Adventures. Where to begin? This is an interesting game that is apperently based on some old stories from H. Rider Haggard. A wrtier from the late 1800s/early 1900s. The game alot like Indiana Jones, The Mummy, King solomans mines and all those other old movies about Adventure man goes to find treasure with Hot foreign girl. I bought this game because I previously played Necrovision and its prequal lost company which the Farm 51 also made. Those were basically doom 3 but ww1. So I thought this would be the same in terms of gameplay. Those games had a terrible story but funny gameplay. This game is nothing like that. It has a decent story obviosly like I said before based on stories and mediocre game play. It tries to do something special with a flash light mechanic but other then just shoot the enamies a lot there isnt much there. It seems also after the graphics update the removed several guns from the campaign and changed animations. In necrovision the guns were pretty well model and the animations were good. Here the guns share very little with their real life counter part. The revolver is pretty bad you remove the entire cylinder from the gun and put in a new one. I watch older videos of this game and it had the correct reload before but they changed it for no reason. The gun play is just meh nothing great. The graphics with everything old the highest are good thow some textures like the water and lava dont look great. The water looks like jelly and the lava like cheese. But generaly the graphics are good. The enamy variety is pretty unique there is a good variety thow they all die in the same way. Shine a flash light on them until they change color then unload on them. Thats for the monsters. Then we have 3 different human factions. Nazi's because every story needs nazis, Soviets because there is Nazis, and Arabs because reasons. Other then shooting the gameplay consist of puzzles, some are fun some are pretty boring. Most are solved by shooting, the others by your flash light or other light source. The dialog is prety good compared to necrovision which I am sad about because necrovision had terrible dialog which was funny. All the voice actors in this game are pretty good, accept for the Nazi guy who helps you his voice didnt fit his body type or look. I am going to recommend this game only if you really want something that harkons back to movies like the Mummy or Indiana jones but isnt movie game. 6.5/10.  I recorded a lets play of this game I will be posting the videos soon. My youtube channel - https://www.youtube.com/user/TroopperFoFo

Posted: March 2, 2014
												Stuck somewhere between action adventure and first person shooter, Deadfall Adventures occupies an epicly mundane place in a genre filled with legendary competition. The tasteless and clunky mechanics leave much to be desired, and the aesthetic elements are graphically lacking. This game tries to deliver too much, and ends up falling flat on all fronts in the footsteps of household names like TombRaider. If you have an urge to putz around a bland and choppy linear environment solving mindless grinding puzzles then this is the title for you!

content:
Posted: August 15, 2015
												1st person, action, adventure, shooter. In this game you play a somewhat dumbed down Indiana Jones type character with everything tied to it, in form of adventuring across beautiful landscapes in company of lovely archeologist, exploring mysterious ruins, tombs, pyramids, caves, jungles to finding long forgotten treasures, solving puzzles and battling evil Nazi and mummy / undead / zombie forces on the way, who want to stop and kill you. Game takes place in roughly 1940's Earth. You will be exploring a lot of ancient places left by old civilizations. There is some real truth and facts about places you visit in history, but most of it is legends and fantasy / sci-fi nonsense. Environments look great, not many games that have Egyptian pyramids in them, I really liked those. There are a lot of puzzles and secrets in game, and they are harder to crack on higher difficulties. There's fair amount of humor in the game. Weapon selection is pretty much WWII timeline, knife, pistols, revolvers, shotguns, rifles, machine guns, sniper rifles, grenades and rocket launchers. Character models are decent, texture quality not bad. Voice acting is decent. Character animations and control was not that amazing, but you get used to it. Personally I didn't really like how main character looks like, he had weird facial animations and didn't look good in cutscenes. Basically it's a run and gun shooter with puzzles and exploration.

content:
Posted: November 19, 2016
												There's plenty to dislike about this game:Unintuitive UI that could have you wandering around for minutes looking for the right thing to click. It's not that the puzzles are hard, but most of the challenge comes from finding the interactable object in each room that will trigger the puzzle event that's blended in with the rest of the scenery and without any indication of its importance. Combat feels uninspiring, it's an Alan Wake-style FPS that requires you to shine a flashlight at many enemy types to lower their shields before doing them in with bullets. This works in Alan Wake with its 3rd-person playstyle and dodge mechanics, but when surrounded by multiple foes, even with a broad FOV, it's very easy to get pummeled when you lose track of mummy #2 and mummy #3. There's very little damage feedback besides your vision getting blurred with a blood.png vignette, and you'll find yourself dying completely unaware that you were taking damage at all.Voice acting and cutscenes are stilted and of poor quality. I get that their localization budget was probably pretty limited, but it's not easy to immerse yourself in the lore or invest in the characters when look and sound like mannequins.However, I will say level design and the use of the Unreal Engine are both very well done. It looks very pretty while at the same time cramming in practically unlimited frames per second. You get a little of the UE-famous pop-in on some textures, mainly during cutscenes, and some mild screen tearing even with vsync.This game should be on the list of anyone who has to play every  action-puzzle game, but definitely not anyone else.

content:
Posted: January 27, 2014
												"Welcome to Deadfall Adventures, an action adventure which seamlessly combines the first person shooter experience with puzzle-solving and exploration, taking players across the globe on a search for a rare and powerful artifact.  Developed by The Farm 51 and published by Nordic Games, Deadfall Adventures utilizes Unreal Engine 3 to produce breathtaking backgrounds and settings, but unfortunately fails to deliver on everything else.  In fact, there were times when I simply wished to put the game away and move onto something a little more stimulating, like perhaps Scrabble.  Or Clue."Check out my full review here, at Die4Games.com! http://www.die4games.com/deadfall-adventures-review

content:
Posted: December 2, 2013
												A strange game, would NOT recommend it for either the combat or it's story - both are incredibly mediocre. Worst is the checkpointing which is TERRIBLE to the point of frustration. However, it's a REALLY nice looking game that makes good use of the Unreal Engine and the way they've implemented puzzles and traps into the exploration side of things works really well - though the occasional instant-death trap does not play nicely with the aformentioned bad checkpointing, as you can often find yourself repeating far too much gameplay because of an unfair pitfall or falling rock.There's enough here that I'd say it's worth a look, possibly when it drops in price a bit, if you're into Indiana Jones or Lara Croft type games. Just don't expect the same attention to story or character development - it's a REALLY perfunctory stab at the genre which throws every cliche in the book at you hoping something sticks.I give it Three Belloq's out of Five.

content:
Posted: August 16, 2016
												Ah...Deadfall. I love the setting, and there are some great moments, IMO. I do love the hectic mine-cart ride and some of the ruins are pretty fun to explore.  The voice-acting is bad, but in an entertaining, kind of endearing way.   The main female character serves little purpose than to b**ch at you, occasionaly shoot an enemy, and get herself kidnapped. But she's British, so that's cool I guess. It's an adventure/treasure hunting game, but also an FPS. This makes for gameplay that's a little different from the others in this genre, but unfortunately doesn't allow jumping and climbing, which is half the fun. Some of the puzzles are cool, some are annoyingly unituitive. Combat is surprisingly satisfying, when it works. Hit detection is all over the place. You can swear you're hitting an enemy with a headshot, but they're just winged. You'll be well out of arm's length, but an enemy will melee kill you in two hits, so be prepared to die a lot (or maybe I just suck) and save points are sporadic.That said, for all it's problems, I found it absorbing. I'll give it a thumbs up, but wait for a deal.3/5: Would Blind a Nazi with a Flashlight again.

content:
Posted: December 16, 2014
												I can only barely recommend Deadfall Adventures..and if you're thinking about getting it for Linux, you'll benefit from excessive loading times and some graphical glitches (though you can still complete the game).  Given that these have been around for most of a year, I wouldn't hold your breath in the hope that they'll be sorted soon.More generally (and I'd imagine that this would apply to the Win version too), puzzles are often weak and some can be solved quite simply by spamming switches if you're too lazy to consult the in-game game guide (i.e. the notepad).  Dialogue between characters varies between dull and cringeworthy and is not helped by the rather awful voice acting.  Combat is so so, neither types of enemy will surprise you in their tactics and weapons, whilst generally doing what you expect, are rather limited in variety. The different shotguns also seem a little on the weak side when they should be at their best (limited range / spread).Cutscene animation was like watching hover-handed people with parkinsons and often combined well with the aforementioned dialogue to make for awkward watching.  Thankfully, you can just click on ahead,Soo, why recommend?  Well the backdrops are nicely done, but more importantly, the game is just well-paced fun - an easy game you can just go back to and be pretty sure that you'll make progress without it being a complete gimme.  Probs best to get it during a sale or in a bundle as the original price is steep..and I can't guarantee you'll get your buck / hour value, but it will be an non too taxing experience that doesn't take itself too seriously.

												So it turns out that the single-player portion of the Free Weekend was actually a demo! Which is good, because I couldn't decide whether I wanted to stop playing it altogether or see how far down the uncanny valley this poor attempt at AAA-dom went.It's actually really boring. The gunplay is bland and they stole the 'use the flashlight to kill the undead' bit from Alan Wake. number of helpful: 8 of 17 people (47%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 8, 2013
												The game was pretty much panned by all critics. In Deadfall Adventures, I never really felt any sort of adrenaline rush from any enemy encounter. The enemies are way too bullet spongey, so it's best to set the combat to easy and save yourself some time; the combat is simply unsatisfying and dull. The AI is laughably terrible and using your flashlight to defeat mummies is no new concept. Metro Last Light used this same mechanic, but it added to the intensity of the battle, which is not the case here. The story, setting, and characters are all extremely trite. The dialogue is painfully bad, and I couldn't care less about the plot, which is sad because I was initially very excited to play a FPS that was inspired by Indiana Jones. Your female companion is often ridiculous to rely on in battle, and much of what she does seems not only poorly programmed but often glitchy.The visuals are the only impressive aspect of the experience, but the animation is very poor. I've been doing 3D modeling and animation for only 2 years and even I could have done a better job with this game's animation. It's just one more blatant problem that works against any sort of immersive experience this game intended on providing. It's a shame, because they must have had some really good artists working on the game. The only saving grace is that cutscenes are skippable. I suggest that anyone playing this game should exercise that option.As far as exploration goes, the puzzles are both frustrating and insulting to one's intelligence, though they aren't as frequent as one would expect. Some puzzles are very obvious while others are difficult for all the wrong reasons, such as knowing a solution but being unable to execute it due to bad programming or confusing hints. There are treasures to be found, but not many, and it doesn't feel like you accomplished anything in finding them. Platforming is nonexistent, as the character can't jump high enough to actually get on top of objects in the game. Even if you could, the incessant invisible walls would keep you from exploring off the extremely linear path the game forces you to follow throughout its entirety.I played this game for a few hours on another account. I really wish people wouldn't judge reviews based on the hours clocked by steam, though I understand that many users are too quick to form a negative or positive opinion of a game. This is something I have run into multiple times, especially when reviewing games that I played extensively before Steam added a system to keep track of the time spent in-game by each user. I promise I would not review a game before giving it enough of a chance to sway my opinion.I mean no offense to those who worked very hard on this game. I know it took a lot of effort and many, many people poured a lot of hopes and dreams into this project. The premise was what sold me on the game. I took a risk and preodered Deadfall Adventures. As much as I was let down, I still have faith that the developer can create a game of a higher caliber. I hope that the developers will learn from the mistakes made on this project. I wish I could say that I enjoyed Deadfall Adventures, and I could see the potential buried deep within the final product. Sadly, the potential never really surfaced. It was more like something I projected onto the game. Still, I hope they try again after learning from their mistakes.

content:
Posted: January 3, 2014
												I thought i'd pitch in my two cents, since I imagine many of you may be in the same situation as I was; wanting to buy the game but discouraged by negative reviews.Well, never fear. I can tell you now that if it seems like you want this game, then you should just get it. It requires a lot of forgiving, but when it works, it's pretty amazing, and very unique - one of the highest fieldety games of this genre by a passionate developer.The Good - The combat is fun, and never ruins the pacing. There's always time to explore. The graphics are phenomenal. Some UE3 limitations pop in from time to time but the overall effect of the art design, lighting and most textures really is brilliant. And hell, the setting. Do you want to go shooting Nazi's, Commies, and Mummies? Good.The Bad - in a way, the game does deserve its negative reviews. The voice acting and animations are juuust that little bit off, but endearing in their own stupid way. The puzzles aren't really puzzles, just guessing games or connect the dots environmental obstacles. The shooting, while fun, isn't weighty enough; and the aiming is a bit sticky. And let's just say that from time to time the game breaks consistency in some very, very frustrating ways.However, i've not run into a bug, or a glitch. From a purely objective standpoint, it's technicaly proficient. And yes, I suppose it's mediocre. But I don't care, I love the ancient civilization adventure genre. And if you do too, you'll forgive this game and soak in the incredible atmosphere. Another bland shooter this is not - check out NecroVision for another shooter set in a visually intense world by the same developer.Besides, when was the last time you shot a Nazi in the face?

number of helpful: 3 of 7 people (43%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 5, 2016
												I knew within five minutes of booting this game up that it wouldn't be a good one. The graphics are fine and the gameplay was passable; but the writing was cliched to the point of self-awareness, the voice acting was abysmal and the animation was somehow even worse than that. At best the game would have slipped by as harmless and charmingly stupid.I've made it somewhere between halfway through and the 2/3rds mark and I no longer find it charming.This game is dumb. Very, very dumb. Putting aside little technical bugs like the compass randomly glitching out and hovering in midair, the gameplay and controls are just sloppy. The FPS elements are harmless enough, you point your gun at the Nazis and the Nazis fall down. It's not especially engaging but it breaks up the puzzle-solving well enough I guess. The puzzles have two settings, irrespective of difficulty: insultingly obvious or impossible to guess. That is to say there IS no puzzle, it's just a stylized code lock with the answer written in your grandfather's all-knowing notebook. The different puzzle difficulty levels seem to only change how hard it is to read his handwriting.To give some very mild spoilers, the point where I lost interest in this game is the start of the Arctic Mines level. It started when after the Sudden But Inevitable betrayal, I'm suddenly in a firefight with Russians of all things. And our 'intrepid heroes' start spitting out the word "commie" like it's five years into the Cold War when up to now we've been fighting the freaking Nazis! If anything, the protagonists actually seemed to think the communists were WORSE, since they were fairly civil when they got pushed into solving puzzles for the Nazis at gunpoint but couldn't go two sentences speaking to the Russians without resorting to namecalling. It was bizarre, like one of the devs bumped into someone working on Call of Duty in the hallway and they got their notes mixed up for a few pages. Complete with an out of nowhere QTE escape sequence at the beginning of the level. If that's the case, I look forward to the inexplicable sliding block puzzle in the next CoD game.That said, it wasn't this idiotic story swerve that made me throw the game in the bin. No, that came a few minutes later when, as I abandoned a terribly-designed platforming sequence in digust, pulled on a lever and was immediately shoved into a cutscene that pulled me past a point of no return (which the game is lousy with) AND autosaved at the exact same moment, making it impossible to backpedal without restarting the level entirely.That was the proverbial straw. I'm done with this nonsense, the game was only getting by on C-list SyFy doofy charm to begin with - giggling at as its Indiana Jones-by-way-of-noir-PI protagonist, his designated love interest by virtue of bust size and open disgust trying to sound like sexual tension, the dialog that sounds like a ten-year-old trying to be clever - and that's stopped being cute. Don't bother with this inept piece of trash.

content:
Posted: November 3, 2014
												Deadfall Adventures may be clunky in places, but it has a heart that’s firmly in the right place. It’s the kind of game that we wish we didn’t have to stick a score to coming from a small studio it was never going to be able to compete with the likes of Tomb Raider and Uncharted. Yet with a decent selection of puzzles and a desire to do things slightly differently, The Farm 51 have managed to make something with the elusive sense of adventure that some developers forget to include.

content:
Posted: September 28, 2014
												This game *is* a bit overpriced for what it is, but it's a very good game. I got it though a humble bundle deal and got like 95% off, which is well worth it.You can basically boil this game to a lower budget Uncharted with basic FPS combat circa the late 90s, some good and sometimes involved puzzles that are varied enough to keep you interested, and a lot of content for a game in this specific genre. The main thing that will make you notice the low budget is the mediocre and sometimes downright awful voice acting and script, not to mention the two generation old animations and models.That said, it's a fun game that *is* worth some money, I would just wait until it's on sale for $15-20 like it probably will be again during the holidays. If you like shooters with some exploration and adventure, this is one of the better, allbeit dated, ones that is currently on Steam.

number of helpful: 2 of 5 people (40%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 21, 2014
												This is a game that wants to be Indianna Jones mixed with some other great adventure stories.Unfortunately instead of Raiders of the Lost Ark we end up with Kingdom of the Crystal Skull.Well maybe that is a little unfair. This game isn't awful, it isn't broken it isn't buggy and it can be fun. Certainly the game can be gorgeous at times and the art direction should be applauded.The weapon selection is limited but is somewhat unique in the fact that they include some real life hidden gems (federov anyone?!?...love it!)The main problem is that the game feels like it could have come out in 1999 the levels, while pretty feel like shooting galleries only broken up by boring puzzle sections (don't get me wrong I don't mind puzzles but these are just particularly bad ones).Enemy AI is also pretty dumb but serves the purpose of moving the game forwards. The story is also pretty hammy but does a good job.The one part that really ruined this game for me though is the voice acting. It is amongst the worst i've seen in almost 3 decades of gaming. It is as if the actors weren't in the same room when they recorded dialogue and more than that like they just pulled people off of the street to do the voices....words cannot describe how bad it is, especially the female lead!In any case i'd recommend this for a lazy weekend if you could pick it up for under $5 and maybe even for under $10. It's not bad and you can have fun with it, look past the voice acting and creaky level design and there is some decent tongue in cheek action it's just a shame as it could have been so much more. Instead it just grinds to an average middle ground.5/10

content:
Posted: June 6, 2015
												I was really hyped for this game but then I end up being disappointed. Despite the good graphics, the story is very exhausting and repetitive. Your partner gets kidnapped, you save her then gets kidnapped again. Basically, the story revolves around this circular plot. The combat system is a total rip-off of the Call of Duty series - the 2 weapon system, the car chase (although in this game, it's a mine cart chase), and the way the human enemies fight you. The only enemies I enjoyed are the mummies. They were challeging and sometimes a pain in the butt. The puzzles were decent and challenging. Although, for a game with an exploration theme, the exploration factor is really limited. You just rely on your compass to find treasures and your grandfather's notebook for the clues in the puzzles. You don't have to explore the tombs for clues or whatsoever. The game was linear, repetitive, and overall, claustrophobic. Don't buy unless it's on sale.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 24, 2014
												I felt the need to write a review for this game as the critics gave it quite a severe hammering on release and I wanted to put a few things right. First, I'll get the negative points out of the way. The game won't win any awards for originality, the story is pretty run of the mill, the combat mechanics are a little clumsy and the voice acting ranges from average to comical. To be honest though if anything these enhance the fun I've had with the game as I figured right from the start that it doesn't take itself too seriously.You play as wisecracking adventurer James Quartermain hired to find a powerful artifact sought after by the Nazis. Sound familiar? Yes, it bears many resemblances to the Indiana Jones movies. It's primarily a first person shooter but with puzzle elements which might not be the most smartly designed and occasionally border on stupid but again, that's half the fun. The locations range from hostile looking temples through Arctic wastelands right through to lush Jungles and ancient cities. The game looks fairly pretty in most places and it all runs very smoothly with no lag or fps drops to be found. There are one or two glitches and some occasional pop in on loading but that's it really. It certainly isn't the buggy mess that some critics would have you believe.One of the main additions to the game is the constant hunt for treasures which act as stat boosters if you find enough. These will enhance things like your health, rate of fire, reload speed etc and while they don't appear to make a significant difference it is however quite fun to hunt some of these down.Obviously being a first person shooter the main selling point for many will be the gunplay. As mentioned, this can be fairly clumsy and the aiming feels like it's on some kind of grid if that makes any sense. It doesn't really take much getting used to and it certainly doesn't ruin the game. As I said, this is a pure old style game which takes me back to when first person games were enjoyable and Deadfall Adventures doesn't try to be anything other than a good fun game. I can't comment on the multiplayer aspect though as I simply have zero interest in multiplayer or online games. I have had a lot of enjoyment out of the single player campaign however, and while it's probably not worth full price I would urge anyone to give it a go if it's on sale.Deadfall Adventures is far from original and it might not be the most polished game but it's still a very enjoyable shooter. If you have any interest in Indiana Jones or the Uncharted games then I'm sure you'll find something you like here. Critics were overly harsh on this in my opinion. Then again if it's not Call Of Duty or Fifa most critics don't seem to want to know these days anyway. I think there's a lot to like here. Sure, it's flawed but at the end of the day it's good old fashioned fun. Something most modern games overlook in my opinion. Give it a try. You may just be surprised.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 5, 2016
												A very mediocre shooter in every sense of the word. The graphics are good, the shooting mechanics are solid, enemies die with good impact and animation. You visit different exotic locales. There's a sense of indiana jones and drake's uncharted. Then there's the problems. You use the same boring 3 different types of machine guns, 1 rifle, 1 sniper, and 2 shotguns, and that's it. You never find anything new and have seen all the weapons half way through the game. You fight the same 2 enemies, regular guys and zombies which you need to use flashlight to kill, which can be very finnicky. Every temple feels and looks the same, so you only really feel you visit like 3 environments total. The upgrades tree is super boring and is just "more health, more stamina, less recoil". The story gets confusing and boring quickly, and doesn't have much intrigue or captivating material. The voice acting is horrendous, as well as the facial and body animations. The pacing is bad. You go through 1 fight, then solve like 2 puzzles in a row, then 2 fights, then solve a puzzle, and so on. There's so many puzzles that it gets tiresome and annoying. Most of them either don't make sense or involve you just looking in your notepad and doing what it says. Game length is decent. Multiplayer is dead. In the end its repetitive and not great, but the mechanics are solid and there's worse options out there. 7/10.

Posted: November 8, 2015
												Don't go into this game expecting big budget quality - This is an inexpensive game that, If I'm not mistaken, was origionaly released on consoles.The Keyboard & Mouse Controls work without fault and you have the option of using a gamepad, The Xbox 360 Game pad was supported out of the box.Graphics are of a high enough quality is determine exactly what you are looking at, If it is of some importance - The weapons have higher detail then the stone walls of the temples for example.I have read some reviews complaining about the audio - the audio is servicable if unspectacular. The weapons, while lacking audio impact, are distinct enough that you can guess what weapon is being used by sound alone with a little practice.I purchased the game while it was on special for $5.00 USD and got about 10 hours out of it, that fits my idea of value for money at approx $1 per hour of entainment (Worked out to be about $7.00 AUD)TL;DRControls Work.Decent Graphics.Decent Audio.Not worth full price.Is worth up to $10.

content:
Posted: March 3, 2014
												If you're a fan of pulp adventures than give this a game a try - however it lacks any stand out features and apart from the lush graphics is fairly bland. I enjoyed James and Jen's banter, and it felt like it had some heart to it. However the combat is extremely simple - it's never offensively bad, although supernatural enemies require you shining your torch on them which makes fighting them a bit more dull compared to the human enemies. The guns, WW2-era, are fun to shoot and fighting enemies feels satisfying, which since there's a lot of fighting is a good thing at least. The Puzzles are very simple, although a few aren't very clear and require a bit of trail and error. Finding artifacts is relatively fun, but they're incredibly simple and don't really require you going out of your way. The graphics are gorgeous though, thanks to the strong art style. Egypt looks like it came straight out of a Indiana Jones movie, and looks fantastic.The story is typical of a classic adventure, taking you to 3 seperate locations around the world. The characters don't have much backdrop, but the main character James is a classic smart♥♥♥♥♥and some of his comments made me chuckle. Jen's a decent companion and despite getting captured a few times didn't strike me as a bad character, just a tad underdeveloped.It's a very safe game, which although I enjoyed the full price tag is too much for what it's offering. I also encountered numerous bugs, including Jen not following me at times (however this didn't stop progress) If we see any more adventures from James than hopefully they'll introduce more mechanics and deeper gameplay, since as it is now it's barely skin-deep.To sum it up, if you can afford the price tag and are more interested in a fun if slightly shallow adventure, than definitely give Deadfall a go. It lasted me about 8 hours, which as far as modern FPS campaigns go is fairly long. If you're more into deep gameplay and intricate puzzles than you would be better off elsewhere.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 8, 2015
												This game has a lot of cool Ideas but the execution is just lacking in too many ways to make it worthwhile.The Good:The premise is pretty sweet. You are a descendant from Alain Quartermain in what is a story heavily inspired by Indiana Jones. Which is a very nice Idea. It's not the imaginative of stories but it works.The overall look of the game is also quite good. Bright desert, moody lighted tombs, blinding sunlight in the frozen glaciers...Voice acting for germans actually made by german native speakers. Yes! So many really big games and movies fail at this. Big tumbs up!The Journal, helping you with the puzzling. You don't need it but it gives hints.The Bad:Combat is mediocre at best, usually ending in "wait for enemy to pop up and then shoot him in the face" or "point flashlight at mummy then shoot it in the face".Voice acting. The effort is appreciated but Quartermain comes through as a chauvinistic loudmouth instead of the laid-back adventurer he's supposed to be.Puzzles are so-so, none of them are complex or challenging but some are frustrating because you have to wait for ages until an object finally moves into position or until you have finally turned that statue 180 degrees.The scripting of the action Cutscenes isn't too bad but they just look so... awkward. And sometimes they just don't make sense. Quartermain jumps on a hook, slides through a tunnel, onto another hook, out the other side of the tunnel.. and his companions stand right beside him. Huh?Consolified controls. Keys are rebindeable (and there's a FOV slider~) but the controls still are very console-y in the way they are laid out.Textures are pretty bad. Rocks tend to be a grey smudge, snow is just a white mess.. meh. Not too distracting but it just looks unfinished.Also the animations on the AI look ... strange. And some sounds are disconnected from the motions. While cycling the K98k the sound plays a much faster bolt-action sound than the model shows..The Ugly:Leveldesign. It seems very rushed. Sometimes you can jump on boxes, sometimes you can't. Some places just outright kill you without the slightest warning setting you back to the last checkpoint and force you to go through the motions of another deadly trap.The game itself presses exploration, stating exploration is key for this game, go explore and find treasure. (As it should be!) But then you are running into invisible walls everywhere. Boxes that you clearly should be able to effortlessly step on are insurmountable barriers all of a sudden. Some rooms that are difficult to find are just empty. What the hell?This game just didn't know what it wanted to be. Action-Adventure? FPS? Puzzle-Game?In the end, it tries to serve too many masters and fails. And it feels very rushed and unfinished, to boot.I can only recommend this on a sale and not full price. (Got it from a humble bundle so there it's alright)

content:
Posted: July 25, 2015
												RECOMMENDED.Great First Person Adventure Game.Huge scenarios with amazing art. Solid story and long enough.It has that adventure sensation you can feel in Indy's films.Lots of puzzles, most of time, very affordable.What I didn't like:Colisions system should be polished, you could be stupidly trapped from time to time, between two objects that seem far enough.There are lots of areas where you should be able to climb or cross by jumping but, there are those phantom walls that avoid it.Some life in scenarios is missing (animals, anything...).Checkpoints. Where will we be able to save whenever we want?.But, none of those ruins the playability or the interest of this game. Think on a mix of Indiana Jones and Thomb Raider but, in First Person and, without the hell of auto-cameras and, without that platform component. Traps, puzzles, original fighting with the searchlight, compass, ...I've really enjoyed it.

content:
Posted: November 3, 2016
												Easy to get motion sickness, changing FoV doesn't really help when he gets back at original FoV when zooming in to shoot.I usually like the story in these kind of games, and that's why I stick with them, but I cannot get annoyed over some things here:- These ancient ruins need to be solved by clearing "elaborate puzzles" where you need your grandfather's notes for. The nazi's, however, don't give a single f*ck, and although you always leave those puzzles in a "finished" state, they somehow always completed it, reset it and made it all ready for you to continue- Some notes from the grandfather are also a tad ridiculous - there's a nazi camp in the artic, which could be fun. but your grandfather - which you assume came here xx years ago - has made a fancy little sketch of the current nazi camp. Nice graphics, atmosphere fails a bit, it's basically shoot nazis (or commies, which are a reskin for 1 level) or mummies (which use an 'advanced' mechanic), solve an easy 'ancient' puzzle to get to a place no one has ever been before (except for the nazi army you're chasing).I would have forgiven all of that and played through, if I could finish the game without getting motionsick and having to quit after half an hour or so. I do not recommend, 4/10. Maybe if you like exploring the same ruins with a different reskin and shooting stuff, without second thought, it'd be something for you

content:
Posted: November 26, 2013



YouTube™ Video: Deadfall Adventures video review - middle of the road gaming 

			Views: 542		

			http://cramgaming.com - A look at Nordic Games/ Farm 51's action first person adventure Deadfall Adventures, which is available now on console and PC platforms.		

Deadfall Adventures review:Deadfall Adventures tells a fairly tame story with larger than life characters and many moments where the action heats up with some cool scripted scenes. The puzzle element is welcome, but in some instances really hinders the pacing of the game. Sadly, the game's characters are simply not likable enough to step beyond being generic, and as a result the story aspect of the game is largely inconsequential. So, what you're left with is a fairly competent shooter, that cleverly mixes in puzzles, throws in some multiplayer and co-op and wraps it up in a neat package that plays pretty well. However, there's simply something lacking from the game in every department, that borders on being dull and uninspiring. As a result, Deadfall Adventures doesn't reinvent the wheel, or tries to, and merely offers a mediocre but pleasant action adventure, that's worth a play but is not necessarily an essential purchase, and certainly not up to par with its peers in terms of quality. If you like a bit of puzzle solving, shooting Nazis and are bored of military shooters, then Deadfall Adventures is perhaps worth checking out, although perhaps it would be prudent to wait for an inevitable price drop.Score 7/10 - Review by Robert Cram

												Well, il start by saying that it was a pleasant surprise to play this game, if you are a fan of the movies of Quartmain adventures, you sure feel inside one of his adventures, the game have a decent combat mechanic and very well made puzzles wich give you the sense of adventurer looking for loot, just like Quartemain.All the diferent scenarios give you the feeling you are travelling around the world, even not using a top engine, the graphics are good and make the enviorement more believable, some animations are fun others a little dumb, but doesnt get in the way of the gameplay.There are some variaty of old model weapons, they feel satisfying when firing them but the little ammo you can carry for each one may feel frustrating in some fights, also they have pretty good sound if that matter for any of you.The Loot incentivate the exploration to get skill points to improve your character and weapons handling, but the levels are very linear, there is 2 or 3 ocasions here you have a little more freedom but, this is a linear game at is core.The Survival mode is very good to play alone or with friends wich give a more extense to the gameplay, or if you are more of a competitive player, the multiplayer is also satisfying with some fun modes you dont find in other games, but in that regard you have better options for the classic modes.Conclusion, it is fresh experience from what we have in the market about shooters, with the adventure touch that make Deadfall a diferent game from the others, and if you fan of QT adventures, you surely feel the similarity betwen them, so id give it a try.

Posted: February 28, 2014
												Enjoyed the demo, may have to increase the difficulty as I only got killed by the traps and not the nazi's. Felt like finding all the treasure locations was the most difficult part of the game when combat probably should be (assuming it gets harder as you play). Voice acting wasn't all that impressive, but the story was one I found myself wanting more of. Pathfinding was a the only real glitch I found, my companion got stuck a few times so she couldn't follow me. Middle of the road FPS but interesting none the less. Not sure I would pay full price, but at 50% off it's definitely worth the buy.

number of helpful: 1 of 4 people (25%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 21, 2014
												This game is everything that it set out to be: a raw, ridiculous good time. The word "thrillride" would be an apt cliche, but it's not quite that, either. Honestly, it's quite boring and repetitive at times, but high points more than pay their dues.  It's got Indiana Jones-style temples, The Mummy-style gunfights, Nazis, Ruskies, mummies, a mine-cart level (because of course there's a minecart level... with lava!) and the ancient curse of Huziwatsisface. If you think these things are good things, you owe it to yourself to play this game and fight your way through the lack of polish, the formulaic puzzles, repetitive fights, and (mostly intentional) cheesy characters.It's not going to win any awards, but god bless them for making this game.

Posted: August 7, 2014
												i found this game to be very fun and interesting. The stroy is decent 6/10. Graphics by 2013 standards are visually good 7.5/10, with just a few slopy animations here and there. But now the puzzles, they are a good blend of thinking out of the box and at the same time common sense and guess work. give the puzzles 8/10. Combat is fun and i admit to being scared by a random zombie head full size on screen. I'd give it 8/10.Unfortunately, the multiplayer is dead though. :/.  Set on hard all around the puzzles can b very tough but, for the experienced gamers, combat remains semi-easy. Altogether i loved this game but i my opinion, get it on sale if u can cause $40 is a little steep for this game.

content:
Posted: October 1, 2014
												If you grew up with treasure finding adventure games then you will like this old school adventure game with a blend of Indiana Jones, Uncharted, and Tomb Raider.  The game is built on an older engine and the graphics are a little dated, but it is a fun story and some interesting puzzles.  Whats not to like about racing against some nazis trying to find some occult power to use in thier quest for world domination?  Its all first person with some good combat to break up the exploring and puzzle solving.  Is a fun playthrough with anywhere between 6 and 12 hours of play depending on how fast you can solve the puzzles and how much time you spend looking for treasure.

content:
Posted: May 2, 2014
												I don't play this too long but I can say it's a good game. Nice graphic and exploring are the best. On every level we can find many treasures and sometimes it's not so easy .. The most helpful are maps which can be found on our way but these maps are a bit hard to read. We must be very careful if we really want to find all of the treasures. Anyway these treasures can help us to improve our skills so we should find them. The next thing I like is soundtrack, it's quiet nice, not as good as in Indiana Jones but it's good :) Now the things I don't like .. The levels (especially outside) are closed, even if it's easy to jump somewhere, we can't do it. Game doesn't let us to go or jump where we want, it's the most dissappointing. Next funny thing is that we can hear voice of our friend even if she is so far from us and the dialog is repeated after 10 seconds again and again. The rest seems to be nice but I must play longer to know that. Anyway, I recommend Deadfall Adventures and I think that 7,5/10 is a good rate.

number of helpful: 0 of 2 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 28, 2014
												Take FPS, Adventure and Pulp genre... if you like at least 2 out of 3 than yes it's worth buying. Each of the elements isn't too impressive but the sum total is very much fun (aside from a few hugely irritating sequences ;) ) Yes the story is cliche, dialog cheesy, characters shallow... What did you expect? it's a pulp game, Yes FPS gameplay is derivative and puzzles while rather fun in themselves don't usually make any sense in the context of the world.The bottom line: pulp game are rare... FPS/adventure hybrids are rare... and this one is very much enjoyableP.S. a word of warning though, take a look at my play time - that's a finished game with taking time to explore and find most of collectibles and considerable time lost on special "die-reload check point-repeat" action sequences.  Basically the game is fairly short, so if you want more value for you money you might want to wait for a sale.

number of helpful: 0 of 2 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 1, 2014
												Man, this game is beautiful. Deadfall Adventures has the setting and story of Indiana Jones, the style of Uncharted and the gameplay of... a generic first person shooter. You play this game from a first person perspective which is actually a very nice twist on the genre. You'll be traveling to different parts of the world to find hidden treasures, solve puzzles and chase bad guys.Like I said, the game has the vibe of Indiana Jones. It all looks very colorful and very adventurous. It has awesome, detailed graphics and horrible, horrible voice acting. A damn shame, because the rest of the game is actually worthwhile, but the voice acting is one of the things that drags the game down. The other thing that drags the game down are the firefights. It's inaccurate and doesn't feel realistic. It's important, because near the end you'll be fighting off more and more enemies.The story is fun in that it doesn't take itself all that seriously. It will be fun as long as you keep that in mind.There are also loads of treasures to be found; some can be found in the open, some are hidden and can be found by simply exploring and some can be collected by solving puzzles. These puzzles are usually simple to solve and can be completed in just a few minutes. If some of these puzzles were only a bit harder it would've given you a better feeling of accomplishment.Doesn't take away the fact that it's fun to try and find these treasures. Treasures can also be used to upgrade your character, but I didn't notice much a difference when I first started the game and when I finished the game. He still felt the same to me.Checkpoints are sometimes awkwardly placed so if you die while trying to solve a second or third puzzle you might have to start all over from the beginning. This can be frustrating but usually it's just a couple of minutes. Still... annoying.Deadfall Adventures wants to be a first person Uncharted and in a way The Farm 51 has succeeded in doing this. Next time, keep the graphics, improve the voice acting and shooting aspects, make the puzzles (a bit) harder and you'll probably have a great, fun sequel in your hands.

												This game is very sloppy in it's execution, but the backgrounds and setting are amazing and the lead characters are quirky and interesting.  The puzzles in the game are challenging, but you carry around a little notepad should you run into trouble that has the answers on it.The firefights are pretty good with puzzles and exploration in between.  I really like that the game rewards you for rooting around looking for treasure, but doesn't just give you the treasure once you find it -- hiding it behind a puzzle to make you work for it.

A damn shame, because the rest of the game is actually worthwhile, but the voice acting is one of the things that drags the game down. The other thing that drags the game down are the firefights. It's inaccurate and doesn't feel realistic. It's important, because near the end you'll be fighting off more and more enemies.The story is fun in that it doesn't take itself all that seriously. It will be fun as long as you keep that in mind.There are also loads of treasures to be found; some can be found in the open, some are hidden and can be found by simply exploring and some can be collected by solving puzzles. These puzzles are usually simple to solve and can be completed in just a few minutes. If some of these puzzles were only a bit harder it would've given you a better feeling of accomplishment.Doesn't take away the fact that it's fun to try and find these treasures. Treasures can also be used to upgrade your character, but I didn't notice much a difference when I first started the game and when I finished the game. He still felt the same to me.Checkpoints are sometimes awkwardly placed so if you die while trying to solve a second or third puzzle you might have to start all over from the beginning. This can be frustrating but usually it's just a couple of minutes. Still... annoying.Deadfall Adventures wants to be a first person Uncharted and in a way The Farm 51 has succeeded in doing this. Next time, keep the graphics, improve the voice acting and shooting aspects, make the puzzles (a bit) harder and you'll probably have a great, fun sequel in your hands.

number of helpful: 0 of 2 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 19, 2014
												Pros:Great pacingGreat (50/50) mix of puzzle solving and combat very well spaced outSolid gunplayCool exotic locationsCons:Hilariously bad voice acting and dialogueCliche storyPoor animations during cutscenesNo manual saves only chackpoint saves (albeit the checkpoint are very well spaced)Deadfall adventures is a FPS/Action Adventure/Puzzle hybrid and it combines and mixes up these elements extremely well to keep the game from falling in a rut.  It's essentially an Indiana Jones type adventure, complete with many familiar tropes, and the story is extremely cliche and predictable.  However it does give you an excuse to visit several of really cool looking exotic locations.The gunplay is solid with the weapons feeling quite different from each other and the weapons that should pack a punch feeling appropriately meaty.  The game even occassionally gives you a fun toy like a MG 34 to play with for a short while. Puzzles aren't overly challenging, even on hard difficulty (you can set combat and puzzle difficulty seperately), but a few of them will at least make you think for a bit.  Most puzzles are thinking puzzles, though there are a scant few that rely on quick reflexes.Overall it's a very fun game if you're looking for an Indiana Jones-esque adventure and can get past subpar production values.

content:
Posted: July 31, 2014
												Personally, I am about 3/4 through the game, and I am really having fun.  I have played tons of FPS games, and this one is unique in many ways.  It's open world, yet you are being led toward an end.  The enemies can be tough, but if you use your flashight and objects in the environment you'll survive.  All the criticism I read, there is some truth in it. Are the weapons old?  Yes... but the game takes place in like the 1930's. Is the flashlight trick kinda dumb?  Yeah, but it's over the top funny, cause it works on humans, too. Is the dialogue fillled with cheesy cynical one-liners? Sure.  But I think they are funny, just like in Duke Nuklem, Deadpool, etc.  My only problem with the game is that even though my rig will chew through graphics on Crysis, Witcher 2, etc. this game gave me lag.  On a 1920x1080 res I tried everything, finally turning AA off did it.  It must be the way they rendered it, I just played Wolfenstien New Order and had it set at 8x I think.  Anyway I would reccomend buying on sale, but not for full price.

number of helpful: 0 of 2 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 21, 2014
												Deadfall Adventures is somekind of a mix between Uncharted, Tomb Raider and of course, Indiana Jones. A piece of warning though... this is a true BUDGET TITLE, so I tried to keep that in mind even though, the game falters in so many ways but somehow, I still wanted to keep going and finish the storymode.The story is very cliché from Indiana Jones, The Mummy, Uncharted, Tomb Raider, all mixed together. The game involves the player into finding some major artifact but unfortunately, it was split into three parts and guess what, you have to search from them until the very end, where you realize that it was all for nothing.The gameplay is lacking. Linear corridors after many invisible ways and glitches aside, the exploration aspect is as rotting as the mummy rot!I'll put the good and bad aspects so you can have a better preview of the overall game.PROS:+Visuals can be good at times but not the characters though.+Diverse geographical locations.+Pretty lenghty for a FPS game.+Weapons variety.+Collectibles found are used in upgrading your skills divided into three categories.+Soundtrack is quite average but does the job for a budget title.CONS:-Poor retelling of a story we've heard countless times before.-Repetitive combat.-Level design in this game is really bad. It's filled with glitches and invisible walls.-Boring puzzles.-Laughably bad voice acting.-Dead or non-existent multiplayer.RECOMMENDATION:Honestly, I'm sure the developers tried their best to make a fun exploratory treasure hunt game but it failed on so many aspects that I find this hard to recommend. The game is lenghty and you do have a few collectibles to find around but beside that, once you do finish the main story mode, there isn't much else to do. The multiplayer portion is like a ghost town although, someone wouldn't had bought this game for the MP! At 39.99$, I truly CANNOT recommend this game for all its CONS but if you can manage to get it around 10$ or less, you may want to give it a shot!The best recommendation I can give you though is to stick with Tomb Raider and Uncharted games. They deliver the stories more professionally and are more enjoyable in the gameplay category.PS. I can't find much of a reason to recommend you the Deluxe Edition as the goodies included can't justify the price, IN MY OPINION! You do get the soundtrack with it and if you're a soundtrack sucker, then get the Deluxe!RATING:6.0 / 10

content:
Posted: May 11, 2014
												MILD SPOILERS ALERT My review might be biased some what. The reason why, is that I love Indiana Jones movies and for a game that some what recreate that experience for me to live it is utterly SPECTACUILAR. The GOOD: The game is beautiful, its not the best graphics but still amazing to look at. I loved how you have a book in your hand which shows you how to tackle puzzle but not make it like a piece of cake for you. The gun fights is decent but not challenging, still loved the variety of guns and how the game forces you to chose new guns rather than stick to what you like. The game also links the puzzles to upgrades by having you solve side puzzles to earn treasures which can be used to upgrade various abilities. It is good to see that the game has a variety of enemies as you will fight mummies, German, Russians and Arabs. each with unique weapons at your disposals as you will tend to pick up their fallen weapons as there are plenty of ammos thus. The BAD: The game is linear in a way that is somewhat cluster phobic, don’t get me wrong for a game that requires you to solve puzzles it requires narrow areas, but since the game itself was able to achieve by landscape for its last puzzle, it led to wonder why this wasn't the case for all the previous puzzles. The game is also very short, I mean looking at the number of hours I have played it above would give you a hint as how short it is, not to mention that I have collected all treasures in one play through. Boss fights are a bit easy and boring, I enjoyed fighting mummies more than fighting bosses. The main character is funny, but I have a Deja vu as if I am playing Duke Nukem all over again, the reason why this is a bad and not a good thing is that, first, I like Duke Nukem to be left alone to be seen only in his games, and two, don’t mix two things I love and expect it to impress me, you are lucky its not in the ugly. The UGLY: The voice acting is, well, UGLY. It is so bad that it over shadows Merritt Weaver Emmy award speech in terms of worseness.  The character modelling would take you back to the time when you first played Metal Gear Solid. I mean for a game that was made on Unreal engine they could have done way better than that. Given the two UGLY things above, resultantly, the cut scenes is something that would take you off of the experience, so much the case that you would dread watching a cut scene. In fact, come to think of it, I believe the game would be way better if there is something that would skip all cut scenes. It is this bad, sorry, this UGLY.  OVERALL: As a fan of Indiana Jones, which the game, to some extent, was successful in mimicking certain aspect of it, I can but only recommend this game as I enjoyed my time playing it and solving the puzzles. The fights is nice way to take you off puzzles and puzzle time is a good way to relax from all the fighting, while mummies, they are there to always keeps you on your toes whether you are solving puzzles or fighting enemies.

content:
Posted: January 29, 2014
												This game is very good in a lot of ways, but lacking in others. First of all, the mummy / zombie enemies that you encounter in the first level are fun as hell to fight and have very realistic movements and amazing models...but you rarely see them at all throughout the game. I'm currently at the ancient Mayan temple part of the game which is the last 3rd or so of it, so maybe they start to show up more just past where I'm at, and I hope they do, because I would have liked to see a lot more of those guys throughout the game than the same old Nazi's and Commie's or whatever. I'm also a bit confused as to why we are fighting both Nazi's and the Russians in this game as its set in WW2 times if I'm correct...the storyline behind your sudden switch in enemies is blurry to me but no matter how it made sense in the game, it was repetitive. Hopefully more interesting baddies will be heading my way towards the latter part of the game. Other than that, the graphics and settings were amazing, the combat was OK. I particularly enjoyed the flashlight feature with which you can temporarily blind your enemies vision. All in all so far an enjoyable, relatively quick adventure story with really cool themes and settings. The enemy base could have used some sprucing up though.
